channel.title: Interface Question
channel.description:
I am hoping that someone here will be able to help me out. I have been reading a lot here and have managed to create a mini updater sort of thing that adds a few accessor methods to the client. I also implemented an interface to the client class using bcel. Now here is my dilemma: I essentially want to call these methods that were put into the client and get the value returned by them.
I know it has something to do with the interface but I feel like I have tried everything. I either get a NullPointer or doing it a different way I only get 0's returned.
So basically I want to know how to call the methods in the client in my "Main" class which loads the modified rs jar. Any responses would be much appreciated and I would be happy to clarify if need be! Thanks very much you guys.

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“light232, post:18, topic:293199”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=387424.msg2901746#msg2901746 date=1249569332]
How are you returning an instance variable from a static getter?
[/quote]
accessor*[/quote]Getter is correct. Accessor is also correct. Move along.

(computing, programming) A function used to retrieve the value of some property of an object, contrasted with the setter. 2002, James Steven Perry, Chapter 2, Java Management Extensions, ISBN 0596002459, page 47: A proper getter must return the type of its attribute.

Read full topic

How are you returning an instance variable from a static getter?

[quote=“oksuper_, post:16, topic:293199”]luptof, you have to cast it.
this.inter = (Inter) theClass4;[/quote]

Thank you very much oksuper_! And thanks do everyone who contributed. It seems that it finally works.

I feel like I’m getting closer! When I try this.inter = theClass4 I get an incompatible type error. theClass4 is an object? Thanks for all the help Unhandled!

Any feedback would be much appreciated!

Edit: It says that it expects Inter not Object.

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @luptof luptof
item.description:
@luptof wrote:

Ah right since the new would make the variables 0. So I took a look at that tutorial. And I have this in my main:

theClass4 = clientClass.newInstance();
		
loadit = (Applet) theClass4;

Is it something to do with this? Sorry for all the questions and thanks very much for your help!

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“luptof, post:11, topic:293199”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=387424.msg2901777#msg2901777 date=1249573067]
Where are you actually setting the value of “inter”? You should be setting it to your instance of the client class, right?
[/quote]

So it would have to be something like:

private Inter inter = new client();

?[/quote]
For your example code, yes…but for a real client…take a look at the bank’s loader tutorial.

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @luptof luptof
item.description:
@luptof wrote:

Unhandled:

Where are you actually setting the value of “inter”? You should be setting it to your instance of the client class, right?

So it would have to be something like:

private Inter inter = new client();

?

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

All the static methods should be stored in client.class which can be accessed when you create a new Applet instance. From those static methods, you should be able to access the nonstatic methods.

Example:
static NPC[] getNPCList()

non-static String getNPCName() - in NPC class

Bot would call getNPCList() and then call getNPCName() on one of the returned instances (make sure the NPC class has the NPC interface)

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Where are you actually setting the value of “inter”? You should be setting it to your instance of the client class, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @luptof luptof
item.description:
@luptof wrote:

Hey sorry, ignore the static. Its more like:

client example

Import com.bot.Inter

private class client implements Inter {

public int getXCoord() {
return a;
}

}

interface example

public interface Inter {

int getXCoord();

}

Main example

import com.bot.Inter;

private Inter inter;

public Inter getInterface() {
return inter;
}

System.out.println(getInterface().getXCoord());

Using this format I receive a NullPointerException. What am I forgetting? Thanks in advance you guys.

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question

item.description:

How are you returning an instance variable from a static getter?

Read full topic

item.title: Interface Question
item.dc:creator: @luptof luptof
item.description:
@luptof wrote:

Hey thanks for the responses. I have tried looking at rsbot source for a guide but have yet to get it to work. For instance, my interface is called Inter. So in my loader I did:

[code]import com.bot.Inter;

private Inter inter;

public static Inter getInterface() {
return inter;
}

System.out.println(getInterface().getXCoord());[/code]

Of course this is just rough work but am I missing something? I only have two classes. One is my main class that contains my loader and the other is my Interface. I am trying to do the above from the main class. Thanks in advance for any help!

Read full topic
